Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding dusty galaxies: as observed, as simulated, and as drivers of galaxy evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative program is to use the spectral energy distributions (SEDs) and morphologies of infrared luminous galaxies to study galaxy formation and evolution. The SED will allow inference of the physical conditions in a galaxy such as the role of an active galactic nucleus in heating the dust. Together with the observed morphology, the program will determine the mode of star formation, and whether it occurs primarily through galaxy mergers or by continuous gas accretion onto the galaxy from the intergalactic medium.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate students, a publicly released SED library, and a publicly released galaxy evolution modeling code.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galaxies are the nurseries where stars and planets form. Therefore, understanding how galaxies themselves form and evolve is crucial to understanding the complex processes that ultimately led to us being here contemplating our origins. Over the past couple of decades, several independent lines of evidence suggest that the growth of galaxies is intimately linked with the growth of supermassive black holes that reside in their centers.  Understanding precisely how they are linked is still an open question, one at the very core of the study of galaxy evolution.  The most active stages in both forming stars and growing supermassive black holes in galaxies are deeply enshrouded in dust. The dust absorbs photons from the X-ray to the optical and re-emits them as infrared photons. We have developed techniques to interpret the infrared emission of such dust enshrouded galaxies in order to disentangle how much star-formation and how much black hole growth is taking place. This is crucial data helping us understand how the growth of galaxies and black holes are linked.
With this project, we assembled a large representative sample of dusty galaxies at the peak epoch of galaxy growth (which was ~7-10 billion years ago). We performed state-of-the-art analysis of their infrared emission thus gaining further insight into the interplay between star-formation and black hole growth in dusty galaxies. One of the broader impacts of this project is that we generated templates which are public and are already being used by other astronomers for analyzing their galaxy samples. We compared the emission from real galaxies to simulated galaxies based on computer simulations that are based on our best knowledge of the relevant physical processes during the most active, dust-enshrouded phases of a galaxy's evolution. The comparison verified some of the assumptions underlying our interpretation of the observed galaxy data, as well as highlighted some aspects where our current simulations/theories fall short. Lastly, we input our new templates into a new model which allows for the statistical interpretation of large samples of such dust enshrouded galaxies observed at different cosmic epochs. 
This was a collaborative project which strengthened inter-institutional ties and provided our students with a wider mentoring and professional network.  Overall, this project already resulted in 8 refereed papers and numerous colloquia and conference presentations to help disseminate the results.  Full or partial support from this grant was crucial in training future generations of scientists including two undergraduate students, three graduate students and three postdocs. Work on this project has helped our students win prestigious awards and fellowships (the Goldwater Award and the Yale Center for Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Prize Fellowship).
